questiontext.text:
Exercise

By reversing the order of the two integrals, evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{@bb@} \int_{x=y^{1/2}}^{@aa@} {@exp@} \; \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y\). Leave your answer in terms of trigonometric functions.

\(I = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{@bb@} \int_{x=y^{1/2}}^{@aa@} {@exp@} \; \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y\) by reversing the order of the two integrals; leaving our answer in terms of trigonometric functions.

It is generally a good idea to first sketch the region of integration. Here it looks as below:

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { // STACK: when moving to STACK change 'jxgboard' for divid boundingbox: [-0.25, {#bb+2#}, {#aa+1#}, -1], keepaspectratio: true, axis: true, showCopyright: false, showNavigation: false, grid: false }); // y=x^2 var f = board.create('functiongraph', [function(x){return x*x;}, 0, {#aa#}], {name:'x = y^{1/2}', withlabel:true, strokeColor:'blue'}); // Vertical dashed line segment at x and y coords var vline_bottom = board.create('point', [{#aa#}, 0], {visible:false}); var line_middle = board.create('point', [{#aa#}, {#bb#}], {visible:false}); var hline_left = board.create('point', [0, {#bb#}], {visible:false}); board.create('segment', [vline_bottom, line_middle], { strokeColor: 'black', dash: 2, strokeWidth: 1, fixed: true, highlight: false }); board.create('segment', [line_middle, hline_left], { strokeColor: 'black', dash: 2, strokeWidth: 1, fixed: true, highlight: false }); [[/jsxgraph]]

To reverse the order of integration, we need \(y\) as the inner variable, and therefore we need to have \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

The integral is taken over the region which can be thought of as being bounded to the left by the curve \(x=\sqrt{y}\). Expressed as a function of \(x\), this curve is\(y=x^2\). Now consider this curve as bounding the region from above, then the line \(x=0\) bounds the region below. These therefore are our bounds in \(y\), and we can see that our bounds in \(x\) are \(0\) and \({@aa@}\)

So our integral becomes

\(\qquad \displaystyle I = \int_{0}^{@aa@}\int_{0}^{x^2} {@exp@} \, \mathrm{d}y \, \mathrm{d}x \)

Since \({@exp@}\) is a constant with respect to \(y\), the inner integral is

\(\qquad \displaystyle \text{Inner} \hspace{0.1cm} \text{Integral} = {@exp2@} \)

And so

\(\begin{align} \qquad \displaystyle I &= \int_{0}^{@aa@} {@exp2@} \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= {@cc@} \int_{0}^{@aa@} x^2 \sin(x^3) \, \mathrm{d}x \end{align}\)

This can be evaluated using the substitution \(u = x^3\)

\(\text{Let} \hspace{0.1cm} u = x^3, \text{then} \hspace{0.1cm} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d}x} = 3x^2, \text{and} \hspace{0.1cm} \mathrm{d}x = \dfrac{1}{3x^2} \mathrm{d}u \)

For our limits, \(x=0 \implies u=0\), and \(x={@aa@} \implies u={@dd@}\)

So our integral becomes

\(\begin{align} \qquad \displaystyle I &= {@cc/3@} \int_{0}^{@dd@} \sin(u) \, \mathrm{d}u \\ &= {@cc/3@} \left[-\cos(u)\right]_{0}^{@dd@} \\ &= {@cc/3@} \left(-\cos({@dd@}) - (-\cos(0))\right) \\ &= {@ta1@}. \end{align}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
